content: Airline passenger screening in the United States has undergone significant changes since the 9/11 attacks, with new technologies and policies implemented by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) under the Aviation Transportation and Security Act (ATSA). The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) was created after the 9/11 attacks to provide comprehensive security screening for airline passengers and property. Congress mandated TSA to implement trusted traveler programs and use available technologies to expedite screening, allowing focus on passengers needing more extensive checks. Subsequently, Congress directed TSA to check all airline passengers against security databases.
